climbs.name: Specter
climbs.fa: Clay Watson, Brian Smoot, Mike Perkins

content.description:
This is a nice line. A steep crux, a vertical crux, an off-vertical crux. Some of the best, most crisp crimps I've laid hands on.

AKA:

Black Power
content.protection: 12 bolts to a bolted belay. Bring a couple of long runners for the middle and start. 70M rope to descend.
content.location:
Look for the black chain/bolt anchor below the black streak. You won't be able to see the climber on the upper crux from here, making sure your belay skills aren't only based on sight.

When we climbed Apparition, we added a two bolt belay about 25 feet left on a ledge that allows you to see the climber for the whole climb. I haven't belayed Specter from over there so let us know if this option is helpful.

The comments below indicate that this kind of sucks so it's not a good idea

. That said, if you go over there, please watch your rope carefully as you lower and clean (especially the bottom bolt).

If

watching your climber is super necessary,

and

you had 2 ropes, you

could

also belay from one of the bolts down on My God, Your God. At least all that rope stretch will make the catch soft.

content.description:
Will the holds appear or not?

Steep face climbing on huge holds lead to a nice, ledgy rest.  Follow the bolts as you climb up under a little overlap and do the killer mantle that you're sure to remember.  Vertical edging on positive holds kicks back to cool climbing through blocks with hidden edges.  Finishes at the same belay as Specter.
content.protection: 12? bolts plus chains.  Its nice to have a few longer runners.  If you come in from the belay on the left (highly recommended as your belayer won't be able to see you otherwise), be sure to have an extra long runner or two.  If you come from the belay below Specter, its nice to have a .75 camalot before the first bolt.  If you get spooked between the first and second bolt, a #1 camalot is nice.  There are some cracks up higher on the route but we didn't like the sounds they made as we hammered around on them.
content.location: About 20 feet left of the start of Specter on the steepest part of the wall.

climbs.name: 37 Problems but a Piton Ain't One
climbs.fa: Clay Watson, Tyler Phillips and Luke Douglas

content.description:
Pitch 1: Either start from the belay at the bottom of the Specter Wall, at the belay for

My God, Your God

or over at

Indie Dog Memorial Route

. Head up the slab passing two bolts then traverse into blocky steepness, passing interspersed gear and one bolt to reach a broad ramp. Continue past a bolt to reach the anchors of Specter/Apparition. This is the easiest way to get to the top of the Specter Wall, making for a great way to work these routes..

Pitch 2: Scamper left from the belay and scramble to a high bolt before launching into 60' of tricky patina climbing, trending slightly right on decent holds to a reachy crux right below the lip. The anchor is over the top on a flat block, two bolts which are currently choking in multiple generations of webbing and cords, faded and rodent-munched. Bring a knife.
content.protection:
Blue tcu-#3 camalot, lots of long runners to prevent drag.

The bolts on top of P2 could use some fresh webbing or chains.
content.location: Left of the Hidden Heavenly Slab.
